posts.title: 3LOQ for Banking
posts.markdown:
3LOQ provides Actionable Insights, at speed. These insights allow your brand to partner with the Right customer, at the right time, to fulfill their purchase intention.
![cover](/content/images/2015/11/3loq-cover.jpg)


##What the project is
The product aims at understanding the connections between products and consumers. Over a large data set, these connections can be abstracted to find patterns among the consumers. 

##Who the team members are 
A 4 member team worked on this product Data Scientist, Marketing Manager, CEO and Product Designer (me).

##Role and Contribution 
Working along with the others my role was to gather all the insights from them and involve them into the product design process. The product to be built would be deployed at the banks for their marketing teams.

##How/why the problem exists 
Promotional messages from the banks to their customers are neglected because they do not reach (1) the right customer, (2) at the right time. Communications right now were broadcasted, they needed to be personal. 

##Why the problem matters 
The cost of customer irritation is too high to be ignored.

##Process 
The team then set out to establish goals and the requirement to attain each goal. 
![image: goals and means](/content/images/2015/11/goals.jpg)

##Understanding the system

The system made connections between consumers and products from the transaction history. But the connections which came out were so huge in no. and wouldn’t explicitly specify the meaning of the connection. We had to find a better way to make sense out of these connections. 

We collected a few connections picked randomly and started researching on them. To get some insights we presented these to domain experts in banking. With their help, we understood that these randomly picked connections could be clubbed to a limited number. 

![Image: connections]

This led to defining something called as contexts.

###Contexts 
1. behavioral indications which determine the interest to buy a product.
2. Each product will have a limited set of contexts which will be determined based on the transactions of the customers who already own it.

##Research
A lot of research was done to gain insight onto the working methodology of Banks. I had gone and spoken to different teams at the Bank. We had also collaborated with other banking experts to gain insight on what the connections meant. 

##Solution 
The final solution had a really simple flow

1. Select a Product
2. Select a context
3. Filter consumers falling in that context to create a specific set
4. Export the list of consumers

##Iterations 
###First
![First Iterations Landing Screen](/content/images/2015/11/3loqIdea1_0.jpg)

The Products list which gives the no. of existing customers and potential customers helps agents determine what product to target.

The idea behind having the action bar was to make the list creation process simple. If these inputs were taken here. The agent can select corresponding contexts in the next screen shown below.

![First Iterations contexts screen](/content/images/2015/11/3loqIdea1_1.jpg)

###Second
The second idea was around a wizard kind of pattern to create a list. This solution broke the flow into steps and let the user make limited decisions on each screen.

![Second Iterations Landing](/content/images/2015/11/3loqIdea2_0.jpg)
####The wizard is a 3 step process
1. Campaign configuration
2. Contexts
3. Export
![Second Iterations Wizard 1](/content/images/2015/11/3loqIdea2_1.jpg)
##Current Live Design
![Current live design](/content/images/2015/11/CurrentLive.png)

posts.title: Xploree - Settings
posts.markdown:
Xploree is a search and discovery platform built over Android Keyboard that offers unified hyper-context and intent precision on multiple screens, multiple apps and in multiple languages.
![xploree intro] (/content/images/2015/11/Xploree.jpg)

##What the project is 
The project was to make it easier for users to configure keyboard preferences.

##Who are the team members
I and Prathyusha (Product Designer) were working on this. 

##Role and Contribution 
My role was more into doing UX research to find the different problems faced and the implications of them. The research made way for different solutions for each of the problem. 

##How/why the problem exists
Configuring a product to the way I work is key for me to use it seamlessly. Inability to configure for various reasons leads to different emotions like perplexity, tiresome, frustration and disappointment.

![emotions](/content/images/2015/11/Emotions.jpg)

##Why the problem matters 
I found that inability to make the product work for you leads to disinterest in using the product. I also found that when people configured the product with ease it’s a sense of achievement. For these reasons, it’s important to make settings easy; Changing a configuration shouldn’t be a task for product owners.

##Current Design
There were two versions of the application.
![Design on which we did the user testing](/content/images/2015/11/Xploree-Current.jpg)


##Process 
There was a huge research phase where I did the following:

1. Understand each setting and who’s the intended user for that setting.
2. The reasons for having some settings as default.
3. Understand Settings of other keyboards
4. Analyze what settings have been configured most versus something that's never done.
5. Understand intended user’s preferences. 

I used different mediums to get data for our research among which the prominent were:

1. User reviews on the play store
2. Twitter views on settings and configure ability
3. Closed survey

###Questionairre
![snapshot of questionairre](/content/images/2015/11/Survey.jpg)


###Research Board
![Research insights](/content/images/2015/11/IMG_1585.JPG)

After the research, we converged again to discuss and we were able to determine that there are the following problems currently in the settings:
![Problems](/content/images/2015/11/Problems.png)


##Solutions 
Each of the problems had several ways in which we could solve it. We independently sketched solutions for each of the problem. We wanted to show the best of the solutions to the Product Managers at Xploree to vote on.
![Solutions for Xploree](/content/images/2015/11/Solutions.png)

##Prototypes
Prototypes were built on Keynote.
![Prototype 1 for XPloree](/content/images/2015/11/Prototype1.jpg)
![Prototype 2 for XPloree](/content/images/2015/11/Prototype2.jpg)
![Prototype 2 for XPloree](/content/images/2015/11/Prototype3.jpg)

posts.title: Imran Parvez
posts.markdown: ## Product Designer imranparvez.al@gmail.com — @imran_parvez +91 9032 920 248 ## Profile Focused on product thinking, understanding users, their online, offline and on-device behaviours and interactions. [LinkedIn](https://in.linkedin.com/in/imranparvez1) • [Twitter](https://twitter.com/imran_parvez) • [Facebook](https://facebook.com/imparvez) ## Work Experience ###Product Designer [@BitChemyVC](http://bitchemy.com) BitChemy Ventures, Sep 2013 — Present BitChemy is a seed stage venture capital fund. * Define product design goals, set design direction and evolve a design strategy to ship the best of products. Mostly using design sprints. * Work alongside R&D engineers, Product Managers and CEO’s of startups to frame problems and solve them. Built web, mobile web designs and mobile application designs for internal products and the start-ups Cafyne, 3LOQ, Kagami & Xploree. * Built the design team from the ground up, iteratively improved the design process with the team. ###Product Designer [@saddahaqmedia](http://saddahaq.com) Viven Infomedia, Nov 2012 — July 2013 Saddahaq is a social news network in India. * Leading effort to build Saddahaq web product, an adaptive news feed, a user-friendly social stream with a variety of news formats and a modular story completion format. * Prototype and designed several animated UI and animated transition for the user’s ease of understanding the hierarchy and aesthetics. ###UX Designer [@desto](http://desto.in) Desto Creative Solutions, July 2011 — Nov 2012 Desto provides simple, creative, useful and beautiful solutions to your design problems. * Developed storyboards and prepared wireframes for various products of clients which include myeasydocs and unmetric. ## Product Design Advisor ###[Shipmile](http://shipmile.com) Feb 2015 — Present Shipmile is a logistics aggregator. ###Chance.fm June 2013 — July 2013 Chance is a new way for Fans & Followers to interact with Influencers, using the power of mobile video. ## Education Engineering Design, Dual Degree(B Tech and M Tech) Indian Institute of Technology, Madras Class of 2012 — Product Design ## Skills Design Skills: Product Design, Web and Mobile web design, Mobile UX, Interaction Design, Information Architecture, Design Strategy Prototyping: Javascript, HTML, CSS, Sketching, Paper, Creation Flow Maps & Diagrams, Low / Hi Fidelity Prototypes in Form/Pixate/Invisionapp. ## Social Proof This is what people I worked with at different organizations had to say about me via linkedin recommendations. > When I think of Imran, the first thing that come to my mind is clear and concise thinking. His ability to frame and solve problems is rare, considering he has been out for college for only couple of years. At 3LOQ, he helped define the requirements and GUI at a very early stage. During this phase, I got a glimpse of Imran’s ability to deal with ambiguities and shape the problem. It’s been great working with Imran and look forward to working together in the future. [Anirudh Shah, Founder at 3LOQ Labs](https://in.linkedin.com/in/anirudhshah) ---------- > Sharp, good sense of UX and highly approachable to discuss multiple facets of the product. Loved his blogs. Helped rework specific aspects of the UX of Xploree with his team and landed some exciting proposals. Best wishes for the next leg of the journey. [Prima Dona, VP Product Innovation, IP, Business Strategy at KeyPoint Technologies](https://in.linkedin.com/in/primadonna) ---------- >I’ve worked closely with Imran on several projects in 3LOQ. Imran brings in feedback and inputs from enough people and knows how to work alongside Product Managers and Engineers. All the decisions he makes in a product have a good reasoning and are backed with strong principles. In the past two years, he worked with us and he also built the design team from the ground up. He brought fun into the workplace in lots of flavors, but the most important thing he brought in was a good process. He is proactive, energetic, fun loving and intelligent. [Kausik Chattopadhyay, Technical Architect at 3LOQ Labs](https://in.linkedin.com/in/kausik-chattopadhyay-0579b64) ---------- >Imran is a naturally-talented Product Designer whose work on visualizing online world, to me, appears as cutting-edge and will contribute in improving the way we look at online space. A guy easy to talk to and with a nice sense of humor, he also makes for a good colleague. [Bhavna Nissima, Communication Consultant and Researcher](https://in.linkedin.com/in/bhavana-nissima-b8328028) ## Side Project ### Jobtrial.co I designed and coded a product all by myself. The tech stack used was nodejs. Check it out at [JobTrial](http://jobtrial.co) ### Publishing Articles I publish articles on new interaction patterns, design research and design breakdowns. My articles have been featured in various websites like Sidebar, Smashing Magazine and MatterMark. The suggestions I gave in my articles have also been implemented in products like @myntra, @mysmartprice etc. Here are some of my best works. Designing Settings Navigating History in Mobiles Cognitive Science and Redbus Notification Overload? Journey of Design in Tech

imranparvez.al@gmail.com — @imran_parvez

Profile

Focused on product thinking, understanding users, their online, offline and on-device behaviours and interactions.
LinkedIn • Twitter • Facebook

Work Experience

Product Designer @BitChemyVC

BitChemy Ventures, Sep 2013 — Present
BitChemy is a seed stage venture capital fund.

  • Define product design goals, set design direction and evolve a design strategy to ship the best of products. Mostly using design sprints.

  • Work alongside R&D engineers, Product Managers and CEO’s of startups to frame problems and solve them. Built web, mobile web designs and mobile application designs for internal products and the start-ups Cafyne, 3LOQ, Kagami & Xploree.

  • Built the design team from the ground up, iteratively improved the design process with the team.

Product Designer @saddahaqmedia

Viven Infomedia, Nov 2012 — July 2013
Saddahaq is a social news network in India.

  • Leading effort to build Saddahaq web product, an adaptive news feed, a user-friendly social stream with a variety of news formats and a modular story completion format.

  • Prototype and designed several animated UI and animated transition for the user’s ease of understanding the hierarchy and aesthetics.

UX Designer @desto

Desto Creative Solutions, July 2011 — Nov 2012
Desto provides simple, creative, useful and beautiful solutions to your design problems.

  • Developed storyboards and prepared wireframes for various products of clients which include myeasydocs and unmetric.

Product Design Advisor

Shipmile

Feb 2015 — Present
Shipmile is a logistics aggregator.

Chance.fm

June 2013 — July 2013
Chance is a new way for Fans & Followers to interact with Influencers, using the power of mobile video.

Education

Engineering Design, Dual Degree(B Tech and M Tech)
Indian Institute of Technology, Madras
Class of 2012 — Product Design

Skills

Design Skills: Product Design, Web and Mobile web design, Mobile UX, Interaction Design, Information Architecture, Design Strategy
Prototyping: Javascript, HTML, CSS, Sketching, Paper, Creation Flow Maps & Diagrams, Low / Hi Fidelity Prototypes in Form/Pixate/Invisionapp.

Social Proof

This is what people I worked with at different organizations had to say about me via linkedin recommendations.

When I think of Imran, the first thing that come to my mind is clear and concise thinking. His ability to frame and solve problems is rare, considering he has been out for college for only couple of years. At 3LOQ, he helped define the requirements and GUI at a very early stage. During this phase, I got a glimpse of Imran’s ability to deal with ambiguities and shape the problem. It’s been great working with Imran and look forward to working together in the future.

Anirudh Shah, Founder at 3LOQ Labs

Sharp, good sense of UX and highly approachable to discuss multiple facets of the product. Loved his blogs. Helped rework specific aspects of the UX of Xploree with his team and landed some exciting proposals. Best wishes for the next leg of the journey.

Prima Dona, VP Product Innovation, IP, Business Strategy at KeyPoint Technologies

I’ve worked closely with Imran on several projects in 3LOQ. Imran brings in feedback and inputs from enough people and knows how to work alongside Product Managers and Engineers. All the decisions he makes in a product have a good reasoning and are backed with strong principles. In the past two years, he worked with us and he also built the design team from the ground up. He brought fun into the workplace in lots of flavors, but the most important thing he brought in was a good process. He is proactive, energetic, fun loving and intelligent.

Kausik Chattopadhyay, Technical Architect at 3LOQ Labs

Imran is a naturally-talented Product Designer whose work on visualizing online world, to me, appears as cutting-edge and will contribute in improving the way we look at online space. A guy easy to talk to and with a nice sense of humor, he also makes for a good colleague.

Bhavna Nissima, Communication Consultant and Researcher

Side Project

Jobtrial.co

I designed and coded a product all by myself. The tech stack used was nodejs. Check it out at JobTrial

Publishing Articles

I publish articles on new interaction patterns, design research and design breakdowns. My articles have been featured in various websites like Sidebar, Smashing Magazine and MatterMark. The suggestions I gave in my articles have also been implemented in products like @myntra, @mysmartprice etc. Here are some of my best works.

Designing Settings
Navigating History in Mobiles
Cognitive Science and Redbus
Notification Overload?
Journey of Design in Tech

posts.title: Research - Designing Search Experience
posts.markdown:
Kagami was one of the products that we were working on at BitChemy. It's a new age ERP software. Design team was asked to research on how can we improve the search experience. This is my research on Designing Search Experience. 

The research outcome was two fold:

* Understanding motivations of search
* Exploring different design solutions

#Design Solutions
In a search journey of any user there are broadly 5 phases. Different kinds of solutions can be designed in each of this phase to better the experience. 

##Prefill
###Educate
There are different kinds of users, users with expertise in the domain to people who have no idea how to use your search. In cases like these you can educate the user on different ways in which they can search.
![educate](/content/images/2015/11/educate.jpg)
###Suggest
In many cases, you can already provide suggestions by predicting or other ways on what he might be looking for. 
![suggest](/content/images/2015/11/suggest.jpg)
###Trends
Trending searches or topics could also provide start point to the user.
![trends](/content/images/2015/11/Trends.jpg)
##Filling
###Auto Complete
Minimizes user's effort by providing him suggestions to complete the query.
![auto complete](/content/images/2015/11/Auto-Complete.jpg)
###Auto Suggest
The domain of suggestions isn't limited to a small spectrum. In such a scenario various things like demographics, profile, trends influence the suggestions. 
![auto suggest](/content/images/2015/11/Auto-Suggest.jpg)
###Scope Suggest
Its quite commonly found in e-commerce applications where the domain of the query is limited by providing suggestions. 
![scope suggest](/content/images/2015/11/Scope-Suggest.jpg)
##Retrieving
###Instant Result
As you type the query the results keep changing. 
![instant results](/content/images/2015/11/instant-result.jpg)
##Display
Search results page is quite a significant aspect of the search journey. *Coming Soon.*
##Re-finding
Re-finding the same search result or entering the same query over time also becomes an essential part of the search journey.
![refinding](/content/images/2015/11/Refinding.jpg)

##Advanced Search
Apart from the above solutions power users or users with vast knowledge of the domain tend to use advanced searches.
![advanced Search](/content/images/2015/11/Advanced.jpg)

Apart from the above solutions power users or users with vast knowledge of the domain tend to use advanced searches.

posts.title: Shipmile Android App
posts.markdown:
Shipmile is a logistics platform for businesses. ShipMile sends the products in the most optimized route to avoid delays and damages.

##A new way to ship
Shipmile is trying to provide a well-packaged solution for Businesses to ship anything. The solution directly integrates into any e-commerce platform providing businesses with an easy and manageable shipping platform.

##An MVP
The team wanted data to build their algorithm, to get the data the team set out to build a consumer facing mobile application which could track shipments for users. 

##Kill two birds with one stone
This mobile application would also be provided as a solution to small e-commerce businesses for keeping a track of the shipments they send.

##Role
* Create a modular design for the mobile application which can be reused for other products at Shipmile.
* Design for Speed to be used by small businesses to enter multiple tracking id's at once. 


##Current Design
![shipmile cover](/content/images/2015/11/ShipmileCover.jpg)

Kill two birds with one stone

This mobile application would also be provided as a solution to small e-commerce businesses for keeping a track of the shipments they send.

Role

  • Create a modular design for the mobile application which can be reused for other products at Shipmile.
  • Design for Speed to be used by small businesses to enter multiple tracking id's at once.

Current Design
